Problem:
Consider a control system governed by \\(\\dot{x} = Dx + u\\), where \\(D\\) is a constant matrix and \\(u\\) represents a control input. When a transformation \\(h(x) = Qx\\), with \\(Q\\) as a constant matrix, is applied, the dynamic response characteristics of the system are altered.

If an intervention using a new transformation \\( k(x) = Rx \\) where \\(R\\) is another constant matrix is applied at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the state \\(x(T)\\) at T > t_1 only be influenced by \\(D\\) and not by \\(Q\\) or \\(R\\)?
Explanation: The introduction of an intervening transformation \\( k(x) = Rx \\) modifies the path of the system in addition to the initial transformation \\( h(x) = Qx \\). Consequently, the final state at time T will be influenced by both transformations \\(Q\\) and \\(R\\), as well as the dynamic matrix \\(D\\). Each matrix's influence is compounded in shaping the trajectory.
